2.title: Introduction
2.content: This reference documents all public hooks (actions and filters) exposed by the SubNews WordPress theme and mesh-core plugin. These hooks enable developers to extend and customize functionality without modifying core files.

3.title: Hook Naming Conventions
3.content: . | Theme hooks use the subnews_* prefix | Plugin hooks use the mesh_* or mtc_* prefixes | Content filters use patterns like subnews_the_* or subnews_get_* | Configuration filters use patterns like subnews_filter_* or mtc_* | .

4.title: Best Practices
4.content: . | Always check hook parameters before using them | Use appropriate priorities for multiple callbacks | Sanitize and escape all user input | Test hooks in a development environment first | Document custom implementations for team reference | .

92.title: Child Theme
92.content: A child theme inherits the design and functionality of the parent theme, while keeping your customizations separate. This is the safest, ThemeForest‑recommended way to customize SubNews because you can update the parent theme without losing your changes.

93.title: Table of contents
93.content: . | Why use a child theme? | When you should use it | Install the SubNews child theme | Where to put your customizations | Updates and safety | .

94.title: Why use a child theme?
94.content: . | Keep your changes upgrade‑safe. | Separate custom code from the parent theme for easier maintenance. | Move your customizations between sites without redoing work. | .

95.title: When you should use it
95.content: Use a child theme if you plan to: . | Add custom PHP (functions, hooks, filters). | Override theme templates. | Make CSS changes you want to keep through updates. | . If you only change colors, typography, or layout using Theme Options, a child theme is optional.

96.title: Install the SubNews child theme
96.content: . | Install the SubNews parent theme first (do not activate yet if you plan to use the child theme). | In the ThemeForest download package, locate the child theme zip (often named subnews-child.zip). | Go to Appearance → Themes → Add New → Upload Theme. | Upload the child theme zip and click Install Now. | Activate SubNews Child. | . The parent theme must remain installed. The child theme depends on it.

97.title: Where to put your customizations
97.content: . | Custom CSS: Add to the child theme style.css or enqueue a custom stylesheet. | Template overrides: Copy the template file from the parent theme into the child theme, then edit it there. | Custom PHP: Add functions to the child theme functions.php. | .

98.title: Updates and safety
98.content: You can safely update the SubNews parent theme at any time. Your child theme files will remain untouched. Read more about child theme .

186.title: Q: Do I need any special hosting to use SubNews?
186.content: A: SubNews works on standard WordPress hosting. You need: . | WordPress 5.8 or higher | PHP 7.4 or higher | At least 256 MB memory limit (512 MB recommended) | MySQL 5.6 or higher | . Most modern hosting providers offer these specifications by default.

410.title: About the Theme
410.content: Subnews WordPress theme is a WooCommerce WordPress theme designed and developed for use with WordPress 5.8 or higher. The code was written to be backwards compatible where possible, however we recommend you use the current WP version when possible. If you are not using WordPress 5.8 or higher and can upgrade your site we recommend you do this before installation. Although every effort has been made to ensure the theme is bug free and easy to use there is always a chance errors may occur. If you do find a problem please notify us immediately through our Subnews Support - Submit a Ticket so we can ensure it gets fixed as quickly as possible.

417.title: Overview
417.content: The Lite Slider allows you to create beautiful, responsive sliders without any coding. Each slide can have: . | Custom background image or video | Rich text content with HTML formatting | Overlay colors for better text readability | Two customizable call-to-action buttons | Mobile-optimized focal point positioning | Flexible text positioning and alignment | . Access Lite Slider: Go to SubNews → Lite Slider in your WordPress dashboard.

419.title: Add New Slide
419.content: To add a new slide, click the “Add New Slider” button in the Lite Slider settings.

420.title: Slide Options
420.content: 1. Background Color . Default: Transparent (rgba(0,0,0,0)) . Set a background color for this slide. Useful when: . | Using no background image | Creating solid color slides | Adding color behind semi-transparent images | Creating gradient effects (via custom CSS) | . Supports: RGB, RGBA (with transparency), HEX colors . 2. Background Image . Required field . Upload your slide background image or video. Supported Formats: . | Images: JPG, JPEG, PNG, GIF, WebP | Videos: MP4, WebM, WebP, OGG, WMV, MOV, AVI | . Recommended Image Specifications: . | Dimensions: 1920x1080px (Full HD) or 2560x1440px (2K) | Aspect Ratio: 16:9 for standard screens | File Size: Under 500KB (optimize before upload) | Format: JPG for photos, PNG for graphics with transparency | . Video Background Tips: . | Keep videos under 10MB for performance | Use MP4 format for best compatibility | Videos auto-play (muted) on desktop | Videos don’t auto-play on mobile (shows poster frame) | Compress videos before uploading | . 3. Mobile/Tablet Image Focal Point . Default: 50% 50% (Center) . Control which part of your image remains visible on smaller screens. How to Use: . | Drag the red-and-white focal point dot on the image preview | Position it on the most important part of your image | Or enter custom position values manually | . Position Values: . | First value: Horizontal position (left to right) | Second value: Vertical position (top to bottom) | . Examples: . | 50% 50% - Center (default) | 50% 30% - Center horizontally, upper third vertically | 20% 50% - Left side, centered vertically | 80% 50% - Right side, centered vertically | 50% 70% - Center horizontally, lower third vertically | . Why This Matters: Large images get cropped on mobile devices. The focal point ensures your subject (person’s face, product, logo) stays visible and centered on all screen sizes. 4. Description . Supports: Full HTML and WordPress editor . Add your slide content using the visual editor: . | Headlines and subheadings | Paragraphs and text | Lists (bulleted or numbered) | Bold, italic, underline formatting | Links | Custom HTML | . Tips: . | Keep text concise for better readability | Use heading tags (H1-H6) for proper hierarchy | Test readability against your background image | Use the overlay color to improve text contrast | . 5. Slide Overlay Color . Default: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1) (10% black) . Add a semi-transparent color layer over the background image to improve text readability. Common Overlay Colors: . | rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3) - 30% black (subtle darkening) | rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5) - 50% black (medium darkening) | rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.7) - 70% black (strong darkening) | rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.3) - 30% white (lightening) | rgba(29, 53, 87, 0.6) - 60% dark blue (branded overlay) | . Tips: . | Darker overlays work better with white text | Lighter overlays work better with dark text | Adjust opacity (last value) to find the right balance | Match overlay color to your brand for consistency | . 6. Slide Text Color . Default: #ffffff (White) . Set the color for all text in this slide. Best Practices: . | Use white (#ffffff) with dark backgrounds/overlays | Use dark colors (#333333) with light backgrounds | Ensure sufficient contrast for readability | Test on actual devices for visibility | Consider accessibility standards (WCAG AA minimum) | . 7. Text Position . Default: Center Center . Choose where your text content appears on the slide. Available Positions: . | Top Left - Upper left corner | Top Center - Top, horizontally centered | Top Right - Upper right corner | Center Left - Left side, vertically centered | Center Center - Dead center (default, most common) | Center Right - Right side, vertically centered | Bottom Left - Lower left corner | Bottom Center - Bottom, horizontally centered | Bottom Right - Lower right corner | . Usage Tips: . | Center Center: Best for hero sections, featured content | Top positions: Good for banners with action buttons | Bottom positions: Works well with people/products in upper portion | Side positions: Creates dynamic, magazine-style layouts | . 8. Text Position Spacing . Default: None . Add additional left or right spacing for extra-large screens (XL breakpoint and above). Available Options: . Left Spacing: . | ps-xl-1--ms-xl-1 - Left space 1 (small) | ps-xl-2--ms-xl-2 - Left space 2 | ps-xl-3--ms-xl-3 - Left space 3 | ps-xl-4--ms-xl-4 - Left space 4 | ps-xl-5--ms-xl-5 - Left space 5 (large) | . Right Spacing: . | pe-xl-1--me-xl-1 - Right space 1 (small) | pe-xl-2--me-xl-2 - Right space 2 | pe-xl-3--me-xl-3 - Right space 3 | pe-xl-4--me-xl-4 - Right space 4 | pe-xl-5--me-xl-5 - Right space 5 (large) | . When to Use: . | Push text away from screen edges on wide monitors | Create asymmetric layouts | Accommodate specific design requirements | Balance with background image composition | . Note: Only affects XL screens (1200px and wider). Smaller screens use standard responsive spacing. 9. Text Alignment . Default: Left . Set horizontal text alignment within the text block. Options: . | Left - Text aligned to left edge (default, most readable) | Center - Text centered (good for short headlines) | Right - Text aligned to right edge (creates dynamic look) | . Recommendation: . | Left alignment: Best for body text and paragraphs | Center alignment: Good for headlines and short text | Right alignment: Use sparingly for design effect | . 10. Text Area Max-Width . Default: Full width . Limit the maximum width of the text content block. Example Values: . | 700px - Narrow column (good for readability) | 900px - Medium width | 1200px - Wide content | 50% - Half the slide width | Leave empty for full width | . Why Use This: Long lines of text are hard to read. Limiting width to 700-900px improves readability, especially for paragraphs. Best Practice: For slides with multiple sentences, use 600-800px for optimal reading experience. 11. Primary Button Link . Optional . Enter the URL where the primary button should link. Supported URL Types: . | External: https://example.com | Internal page: /about-us/ | Anchor link: #section-id | Email: mailto:info@example.com | Phone: tel:+1234567890 | . Tips: . | Use absolute URLs for external links | Test all links after publishing | Consider opening external links in new tab (via custom code) | . 12. Primary Button Text . Optional . Enter the text displayed on the primary button. Examples: . | “Learn More” | “Get Started” | “Shop Now” | “View Portfolio” | “Contact Us” | “Download Free Guide” | . Best Practices: . | Use action-oriented text | Keep it short (2-4 words) | Make it specific and clear | Avoid generic “Click Here” | . 13. Secondary Button Link . Optional . Enter the URL for the secondary (second) button. Same format as Primary Button Link. When to Use Secondary Button: . | Offer alternative action (e.g., “Learn More” + “Watch Video”) | Provide choice (e.g., “Buy Now” + “Try Demo”) | Create hierarchy of actions | . 14. Secondary Button Text . Optional . Text for the secondary button. Examples: . | “Watch Video” | “Learn More” | “See Demo” | “View Details” | . Tip: Secondary button should represent a less prominent action than primary button.

423.title: 2. Enable Slider Arrow

425.title: 4. Slide Interval Time
425.content: Default: 7000 (7 seconds) . Time in milliseconds between automatic slide transitions. Common Values: . | 0 - Disable autoplay (manual navigation only) | 5000 - 5 seconds (fast) | 7000 - 7 seconds (default, recommended) | 10000 - 10 seconds (slow, good for text-heavy slides) | 15000 - 15 seconds (very slow) | . Conversion: . | 1 second = 1000 milliseconds | 5 seconds = 5000 | 7 seconds = 7000 | 10 seconds = 10000 | . Recommendations: . | Image-focused: 5-7 seconds | Text-heavy: 8-12 seconds | Videos: Disable autoplay (set to 0) | Call-to-action: 7-10 seconds (give time to read and click) | . 426.title: 5. Select Slider Animation
426.content: Default: Slide . Choose the transition effect between slides. Animation Options: . Slide (Default) . | Classic horizontal sliding effect | Smooth left-to-right transition | Works well with all content types | Most familiar to users | Best performance | . Fade In (Carousel Fade) . | Cross-fade transition | Current slide fades out while next fades in | Elegant, sophisticated effect | Good for image-heavy sliders | Best for high-quality photos | Creates seamless transition | . Which to Choose: . | Slide: Dynamic, directional, classic (recommended for most cases) | Fade: Elegant, smooth, modern (best for portfolios, photography) | . Performance Note: Both animations are optimized and perform well on all devices.

427.title: 6. Slider Bottom Separator

Wave Separators: . | wave1 through wave15 - 15 different wave patterns | Smooth, organic shapes | Great for modern, flowing designs | . Opacity Separators: . | curve-asym-opacity - Asymmetric curve with gradient | fan-opacity - Fan/radial pattern with fade | tilt-opacity - Tilted separator with transparency | . Geometric Separators: . | curve - Simple curved separator | triangle - Triangular point separator | triangle-edge - Sharp triangle edge | tilt - Diagonal slanted separator | arrow - Arrow-shaped separator | book - Book fold effect | . Themed Separators: . | clouds - Cloud shapes | iceberg - Iceberg peaks | city-skyline - City building silhouettes | faded-triangle - Gradient triangle | . Creative Separators: . | torn-paper - Torn paper edge effect | music-notes - Musical note decorations | paint-drip - Paint dripping effect | . Choosing a Separator: . | Waves: Universal, works with any theme | Geometric: Clean, modern designs | Themed: Match your content (city for urban, clouds for sky/travel) | Creative: Bold, artistic designs | . Example Use Cases: . | Ocean/water theme → wave1-wave15 | Tech/modern → tilt, triangle | Nature/organic → clouds, curve | Creative/artistic → paint-drip, torn-paper | Music/entertainment → music-notes | .

428.title: 7. Separator Height
428.content: Default: Empty (uses separator’s default height) . Set the height of the SVG separator in pixels. Recommended Values: . | 50 - Subtle, small separator | 100 - Medium separator (recommended) | 150 - Large separator | 200 - Extra large, dramatic effect | . Tips: . | Larger heights create more dramatic visual impact | Smaller heights are more subtle | Test on mobile - separators scale responsively | Adjust based on your overall design | . Note: Enter number only (without “px”). Example: 100 .

429.title: 8. Separator Background Color
429.content: Default: Transparent/None . Set the fill color for the SVG separator. Common Uses: . | Match your page background color | Match section below slider | Use brand colors | Create contrast | . Examples: . | #ffffff - White (for white page backgrounds) | #f8f9fa - Light gray | #1a1a1a - Dark background | rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1) - Semi-transparent | . Best Practice: Set this to match the background color of the section directly below your slider for seamless integration.

430.title: 9. Flip/Inverted Separator
430.content: Default: Default (no flip) . Flip or mirror the separator shape. Options: . | Default - Original orientation (no flip) | Flip Vertically - Flip up to down (mirror vertically) | Flip Horizontally - Flip right to left (mirror horizontally) | Flip Vertically & Horizontally - Flip both directions | . When to Use: . | Flip Vertically: Reverse separator direction (point up instead of down) | Flip Horizontally: Reverse asymmetric separators for variety | Both: Complete 180° rotation for unique effects | . Creative Use: Try different flip options to see which looks best with your specific separator and design.

677.title: Server Requirements for SubNews
677.content: SubNews works best on the latest version of WordPress. If you are not on the latest version, make sure you are running WordPress 5.8 or higher.

678.title: Minimum requirements (WordPress)
678.content: WordPress recommends: . | PHP version 7.4 or greater. | MySQL version 5.6 or greater OR MariaDB version 10.1 or greater. | HTTPS support. | . For the latest WordPress requirements, see: WordPress Requirements.

679.title: Recommended PHP configuration
679.content: Low PHP limits can cause issues like demo import failures, slow admin screens, or timeouts. We recommend at least the following: . | memory_limit 256M | max_input_vars 3000 | max_execution_time 180 | post_max_size 32M | upload_max_filesize 32M | allow_url_fopen On | . If you are unsure how to check these values, ask your host to confirm or adjust them for you.

680.title: Increase the WordPress memory limit
680.content: If demo import runs out of memory, raise the WordPress memory limit. You can do this yourself or ask your host to do it for you.

681.title: Do It Yourself
681.content: To adjust on your own, here are some methods to try. Be aware that this section requires advanced knowledge; it is not basic.

682.title: Edit your wp-config.php file
682.content: Add this near the top, before the line that says “Happy Blogging”: . define('WP_MEMORY_LIMIT', '256M'); . WordPress memory can be different from the server. Set this regardless of server memory settings. Read More About Editing wp-config.php .

683.title: Edit your PHP.ini file
683.content: If you have access to your php.ini file, update the line below. If it shows 64M, try 256M: . memory_limit = 256M ; Maximum amount of memory a script may consume (64MB) .

684.title: Edit your .htaccess file
684.content: If you don’t have access to php.ini, try adding this to your .htaccess file: . php_value memory_limit 256M .

685.title: Contact Your Host
685.content: If you are not comfortable with the steps above or they do not work, ask your host to increase the memory limit for you.

990.title: Why Security Matters
990.content: WordPress powers 43% of all websites, making it a prime target for attackers.

991.title: Security Risks
991.content: Without proper security, your site faces: . | Data Breaches - Stolen customer information | Malware Infections - Malicious code injection | SEO Spam - Hidden links damage rankings | Defacement - Site content replaced | Downtime - Loss of revenue and reputation | Blacklisting - Removed from Google search results | Legal Issues - GDPR violations, liability claims | .

992.title: Security Benefits
992.content: A secure website provides: . | Protection for visitor data | Maintained SEO rankings | Brand reputation protection | Customer trust and confidence | Business continuity | Compliance with regulations | Peace of mind | . Remember: Prevention is easier and cheaper than recovery.

994.title: 1. Brute Force Attacks
994.content: What it is: Automated attempts to guess login credentials by trying thousands of username/password combinations. Signs: . | Multiple failed login attempts | Slow admin dashboard | High server load | Login lockout messages | . Prevention: . | Strong passwords (see Password Security section) | Limit login attempts | Two-factor authentication | Change default admin username | Use CAPTCHA on login page | .

995.title: 2. Malware Infections
995.content: What it is: Malicious code injected into your site to steal data, redirect visitors, or send spam. Signs: . | Unexpected redirects | Unknown admin users | Modified core files | Spam content appearing | Google blacklist warning | . Prevention: . | Keep WordPress updated | Use security plugins | Regular malware scans | File integrity monitoring | Secure file permissions | .

996.title: 3. SQL Injection
996.content: What it is: Attackers insert malicious SQL code into input fields to access or manipulate your database. Signs: . | Unauthorized database changes | Exposed user data | Site defacement | Unexpected admin users | . Prevention: . | Keep WordPress updated (WordPress prevents this) | Use prepared statements in custom code | Input validation and sanitization | Web Application Firewall (WAF) | Security plugins with SQL injection protection | .

997.title: 4. Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
997.content: What it is: Malicious scripts injected into web pages viewed by other users. Signs: . | Unwanted JavaScript execution | Cookie theft | Session hijacking | Unexpected pop-ups | . Prevention: . | Keep WordPress and plugins updated | Input sanitization | Output escaping (SubNews does this properly) | Content Security Policy headers | Security plugins | .

998.title: 5. DDoS Attacks
998.content: What it is: Overwhelming your server with traffic to make your site unavailable. Signs: . | Site extremely slow or down | High server resource usage | Increased traffic from suspicious sources | Multiple requests from same IPs | . Prevention: . | Use Cloudflare (free DDoS protection) | Server-level firewalls | Rate limiting | CDN service | Quality hosting provider | .

999.title: 6. Phishing & Social Engineering
999.content: What it is: Tricking users into revealing credentials or sensitive information. Signs: . | Fake login emails | Suspicious password reset requests | Unusual admin access | Social media account compromise | . Prevention: . | User education and training | Verify email authenticity | Never share login credentials | Use official WordPress.org resources only | Enable two-factor authentication | .

1000.title: 7. File Upload Vulnerabilities
1000.content: What it is: Malicious files uploaded through forms, plugins, or media library. Signs: . | Unknown files in uploads folder | PHP files in image directories | Unexpected file types | Backdoor access | . Prevention: . | Restrict file upload types | Use security plugins | Regular file scans | Proper file permissions | Disable PHP execution in uploads folder | .

1001.title: 8. Outdated Software
1001.content: What it is: Running old versions of WordPress, plugins, or themes with known vulnerabilities. Signs: . | Update notifications | Security plugin warnings | Vulnerability scan alerts | Compatibility issues | . Prevention: . | Enable automatic WordPress updates | Update plugins immediately | Update themes regularly | Remove unused plugins/themes | Test updates on staging site first | .

1032.title: WordPress Hardening
1032.content: Make WordPress more secure by limiting access and removing vulnerabilities.

1033.title: Disable File Editing
1033.content: Prevents hackers from editing theme/plugin files from dashboard. Add to wp-config.php: . // Disable file editor define('DISALLOW_FILE_EDIT', true); .

1034.title: Disable Plugin/Theme Installation
1034.content: Prevents unauthorized plugin installations. Add to wp-config.php: . // Disable plugin/theme installation define('DISALLOW_FILE_MODS', true); .

1035.title: Change Database Table Prefix
1035.content: Default wp_ prefix makes SQL injection easier. During Installation: Change prefix to something unique like sn47_ or xyz_ . After Installation (Advanced): Use “Change Table Prefix” plugin or manual database changes (risky).

1036.title: Hide WordPress Version
1036.content: Remove version info from source code. Add to functions.php (child theme): . // Remove WordPress version remove_action('wp_head', 'wp_generator'); // Remove version from RSS add_filter('the_generator', '__return_empty_string'); .

1037.title: Disable XML-RPC
1037.content: XML-RPC can be exploited for brute force attacks. Via Plugin: Install “Disable XML-RPC” plugin. Via .htaccess: . # Block XML-RPC <Files xmlrpc.php> order deny,allow deny from all </Files> .

1038.title: Protect wp-config.php
1038.content: Most important WordPress file - contains database credentials. Add to .htaccess: . # Protect wp-config.php <files wp-config.php> order allow,deny deny from all </files> .

1039.title: Disable Directory Browsing
1039.content: Prevent listing of directory contents. Add to .htaccess: . # Disable directory browsing Options -Indexes .

1040.title: Limit Login Attempts
1040.content: Prevent brute force attacks. Via Plugin: Install “Limit Login Attempts Reloaded” . Settings: . | 5 attempts allowed | 20-minute lockout | 24-hour lockout after 4 lockouts | .

1041.title: Change Login URL
1041.content: Hide default /wp-admin login page. Via Plugin: Install “WPS Hide Login” . Settings: . | Go to Settings → WPS Hide Login | Change login URL to something unique | Example: yourdomain.com/secure-login-2024 | Save settings | Bookmark new URL! | . ⚠️ Important: Save new URL or you’ll be locked out! .

1042.title: Disable Author Archives
1042.content: Prevents username enumeration. Add to functions.php: . // Disable author archives add_action('template_redirect', function() { if (is_author()) { wp_redirect(home_url()); exit; } }); .

1043.title: Security Headers
1043.content: Add security headers via .htaccess: . # Security Headers <IfModule mod_headers.c> # Prevent clickjacking Header set X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN" # Prevent MIME type sniffing Header set X-Content-Type-Options "nosniff" # Enable XSS protection Header set X-XSS-Protection "1; mode=block" # Referrer policy Header set Referrer-Policy "strict-origin-when-cross-origin" # Content Security Policy (adjust as needed) Header set Content-Security-Policy "default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline';" </IfModule> .

1087.title: First Steps for Any Issue
